issues.title: `sspush` / `sspop`: Encoding ambiguity
issues.body:
Two instructions: `sspush` and `sspop` share the same encoding except:
*   `sspush`: `rs1`==source operand, `rd`==0
*   `sspop`: `rs1`==0, `rd`==destination operand

If both `rs1` and `rd` are zero, `sspush x0` and `sspop x0` are indistinguishable.

Quoting "4.1. Push to and Pop from the shadow stack":
> the CFI extension provides the `x1` and `x5` variants of the shadow stack load and store.

It (this sentence from a note) suggests that `sspush` and `sspop` only allows either `x1` or `x5` but this is not clear from the specification.

How do we resolve this?  Here are some ideas to resolve:

1.  ~~Only allow `x1` and `x5` as `sspush` and `sspop` instruction operand~~
2.  Disallow `x0` on `sspush` and `sspop` instructions (but allow other registers)
3.  ~~Use different encodings (e.g. use different `funct3`) between `sspush` and `sspop` instructions~~
4.  ~~Define the special behavior (explicitly) if an operand of `sspush` or `sspop` is `x0` (I don't like this option though)~~

issues.title: `ssamoswap`, `lpsll` and `lpcll`: Encoding ambiguity
issues.body:
Those three instructions share the same encoding space (same major opcode, funct7 and funct3):

```
ssamoswap : 1000001 src||addr 100 dst 1110011
lpsll     : 1000001   0||LLPL 100   0 1110011
lpcll     : 1000001   1||LLPL 100   0 1110011
```

and `lpsll` and `lpcll` instructions are indistinguishable from the `ssamoswap` instruction with `rd` of `x0`.

If sharing the encoding space is expected, `ssamoswap` must prohibit destination zero register.

issues.title: `sschkra`: strange encoding or operand ordering
issues.body:
Despite that `sschkra` is encoded as `rs1==5` and `rs2==1`, the only example of this instruction shows: `sschkra x1, x5`.
If two operands are encoded as `rs1` and `rs2`, it usually means `rs1==1` and `rs2==5`.  This is rather strange.

Changing encoding and/or operands of this instruction may be required.
Note that not all options are mutually exclusive (e.g. 1 and 3 are not mutually exclusive).

1.  ~~Change encoding of `sschkra` so that `rs1==1` and `rs2==5`.~~
2.  Accept only `sschkra x5, x1` and change the example in the specification.
3.  ~~Accept both `sschkra x1, x5` and `sschkra x5, x1`, assign them the same opcode.~~
4.  ~~Remove both operands from the assembler mnemonics of `sschkra` (to encode `sschkra` instruction with just `sschkra`, not `sschkra x1, x5` or something) and make `x1` and `x5` implicit.~~

~~Note that `sschkra` instruction shares the same major opcode, funct7 and funct3 with `lpsul` and `lpcul` instructions but it is safe to swap `(rs1,rs2)==(5,1) â†’ (1,5)` as in option 1 because doing so does not cause crash to `lpsul` and `lpcul` instructions (to NOT crash with `lpsul` and `lpcul`, register number of `rs2` must be less than 16).~~

issues.title: State leakage and burden of clearing of CSRs even if it's not enabled
issues.body:
LPLR and SSP CSRs are unprivileged CSRs and their access is gated via menvcfg.CFI and henvcfg.CFI

IIRC, earlier these CSR accesses were gated via xcfistatus enable bits. Thus any access to SSP/LPLR CSRs in U mode (if not enabled) would've led to illegal instruction fault.

As per current spec, to prevent leakage; LPLR/SSP need to be context switched unconditionally whether a mode/u mode task has it enabled or not (because access to the CSR is allowed).

Is this intentional?

issues.title: ssamoswap in privileged mode
issues.body:
Earlier spec (when xcfistatus existed), ssamoswap could be performed by S mode on U mode SS memory to do some fixups.

Now ssamoswap is gated on `xBCFIACT` which will be 0 when in S mode and `mstatus.SBCFIEN = 0`

This forces S mode to create alias mapping whenever it wants to do some fixup in less priv SS memory.

Can we have a new instruction for higher mode to perform fixup on less priv mode SS memory?

issues.title: Proposal: Add dependency to `Zicsr`
issues.body:
This is the same series of proposals (add dependency to `Zicsr` from unprivileged extensions with CSR):

*   riscv/riscv-code-size-reduction#179 (Resolved)
*   riscv/riscv-j-extension#17 (Resolved)
*   riscv/riscv-p-spec#145 (open but will be reflected)

Although `Zisslpcfi` has privileged part (all privileged extensions have indirect dependency to `Zicsr` through the privileged architecture), this extension contains user-accessible CSRs.  So, adding `Zicsr` to the dependency would be nice and clearer (for toolchains implementing this `Zisslpcfi` extension).

issues.title: Errors on atomic swap example
issues.body:
The backward-edge CFI provides following example for atomic swap.
```
# The a0 register holds the pointer to top of new shadow
# to switch to. The current ssp is first pushed on the current
# shadow stack and the ssp is restored from new shadow stack
save_shadow_stack_pointer:
    ssprr  x5                   # read ssp and push value onto
    sspush x5                   # shadow stack. The [ssp] now
                                # holds ssp+8. Save away x5
                                # into a context structure to
                                # restore later.
restore_shadow_stack_pointer:
    ssamoswap t0, a0, x0        # t0=*[ssp] and *[ssp]=0
    addi      t0, t0, (XLEN/8)  # t0+XLEN/8 must match to a0
    bnez      t0, a0, crash     # if not crash program
    csrw      ssp, t0           # setup new ssp
```
There is an error on restore function. The `a0` register is expected to hold the memory address stored the checkpoint, the value should be `ssp`. Therefore, the value of `*[a0]` is expected to be `ssp+(XLEN/8)`, and the `t0` register is holding the value after `ssamoswap` instruction. In order to check the equivalent of the `t0` and `a0` register, you need to add `(XLEN+8)` to the `a0` register instead of the `t0` register. The correct equation would be: `t0 == a0+(XLEN/8)`. The `t0` register is still holding the top return address pointer, `ssp+(XLEN/8)`, after equivalent check.

The updated example is shown as following:
```
# The a0 register holds the pointer to top of new shadow
# to switch to. The current ssp is first pushed on the current
# shadow stack and the ssp is restored from new shadow stack
save_shadow_stack_pointer:
    ssprr  x5                   # read ssp and push value onto
    sspush x5                   # shadow stack. The [ssp] now
    addi   x5, x5, -(XLEN/8)    # holds ssp+(XLEN/8). The [x5]
                                # now holds ssp. Save away x5
                                # into a context structure to
                                # restore later.
restore_shadow_stack_pointer:
    ssamoswap t0, a0, x0        # t0=*[a0] and *[a0]=0
                                # The [a0] should hold ssp
    addi      a0, a0, (XLEN/8)  # a0+XLEN/8 must match to t0
    bne       t0, a0, crash     # if not crash program
    csrw      ssp, t0           # setup new ssp
```

issues.title: Binary distance between lpcll and lpsll issue for microarch/physical attacks?
issues.body:
I think this CFI extension might be the target for physical attacks.

There is a risk that a lpcll may be maliciously transformed into a lpsll.
Or a lpcml into a lpcll

With a bit of luck an attacker may change the label expected value with a glitched landing pad of the same value...

I know that there is example for such type attacks on other architectures.

I link a paper that has a nice introduction to the issue (just read the physical Attacks section)

https://past.date-conference.com/proceedings-archive/2019/pdf/1074.pdf

I'm not sure but I think that it the binary distance between these two critical instructions was higher the risk might be reduced.

Was this issues considered? Is there any mitigation planned?

issues.title: Rename lplr to lpl
issues.body: The `lplr` name is to be replaced by `lpl`. Including the "r" at the end of a register has fallen out of favor, since the "r" follows from it being a CSR. This CSR does not need to be unprivileged.

issues.title: Hidden Execution Path of Backward Edge CFI
issues.body: In [this](https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.08229) ROP attack paper, the authors managed to attack RISC-V using hidden execution path in the code. The return instructions return to the addresses which are not the instruction heads. This only happen when C extension is enabled. In this case, the attacker may find return instruction without the shadow stack protection to construct the gadgets.

issues.title: ELP behaviour on bad target instruction
issues.body:
I ran into an issue with my implementation of forward CFI which, unless I am missing something, was caused by the proposed standard being incorrect.

"When ELP is set to LP_EXPECTED and the next instruction in the instruction stream is not lpcll, then an illegal instruction exception is raised. If the next instruction in the instruction stream is lpcll then the ELP updates to NO_LP_EXPECTED."
...
"When the instructions cause an illegal-instruction exception, the ELP does not change."

The second statement means that the fault handler will be entered with ELP still set. If forward CFI is enabled in the handler's mode (I was running tests in machine mode, so there was no way to avoid that) this in turn means that the first statement requires the fault handler to begin with a matching lpcll, or you get a never-ending fault loop...

There is a later statement:
"When a trap is taken into privilege mode x, the xPELP bits are updated with current ELP and ELP is set to NO_LP_EXPECTED."
but that is in a chapter that explicitly talks about:
"A trap may need to be delivered to the same or higher privilege level on completion of JALR but before the instruction at the target of JALR was decoded..."


I suggest removing the second statement above and making it clear what the intended behaviour is when faulting due to lack of lpcll after call (or when the ID is wrong).
In my "fixed" implementation, I now _always_ clear ELP for every instruction that is not supposed to actually set it. If ELP was set before there are then three possible situations:
1 The new instruction is a correct lpcll - everything is fine
2 There was an exception so the instruction was not executed - old ELP state copied into xPELP and exception handler called
3 The new instruction was not an lpcll, or was an lpcll at an unaligned address or with wrong ID - old ELP state copied into xPELP and fault handler called.
AFAICT, that should always work fine.


It is still unclear whether xPELP is supposed to be set when faulting in case 3.
Is it useful to be able to see in the fault handler whether this was a "normal" illegal instruction or a CFI error? I suppose one can still find that out by looking at the instruction.

issues.title: Priority of forward CFI fault?
issues.body:
In my implementation of CFI, the checks need to be done late in the CPU pipeline. This means that a lot of other things have been checked before it is decided whether a call target has the expected lpcll.
For example, the target instruction could be illegal, a misaligned branch, a faulting memory access etc.

All such things will of course also cause a fault handler to be called, and some of them will eventually cause the instruction in question to be restarted - whereupon any CFI fault will be taken.
Still, for the cases where an instruction restart does _not_ happen (there is another fatal fault), do we want there to be some kind of fault prioritization, or does it not matter?

Whether prioritization is expected or not should (IMHO) be documented.

issues.title: Updates to shadow stack instructions
issues.body:
Architecture committee reviewed the SS-LP-CFI instructions and various points of discussion led to the conclusion that the new SS-LP-CFI instructions will be common and code size will be a material concern and ARC has suggested the following updates:
- Combine `sspop` and `sschkra` into a single instruction - `sspopchk`. The pros and cons of combining two of the instructions into one somewhat more CISC'y instruction - to reduce code size (as well as eliminate use of a result Xreg and needing to specify it in the instruction encoding) - was discussed. The recommendation is to take this latter approach, resulting in just two SS-LP-CFI instructions (the CISCy-ness is considered very limited, especially when performed using cacheable idempotent memory, and felt to be justified in this case).
- The TG suggested that the `sspop` as defined is retained to support mode of operation where shadow stack is the only return address stack. This would be usable by `-march=native` binaries and also JIT code. Binaries built in this fashion will not be portable. There are issues with providing compressed instructions for both this purpose and for the shadow stack checking addition, and so the ARC proposes that only the shadow checking instructions would be have compressed format Zimops definitions, and the new ABI would need to use new non-Zimops instructions.
- The `sspush`,  `sspop`, `ssamoswap`, and `sspopchk` instructions should be specified as requiring use of idempotent cacheable memory (and otherwise a fault can be taken as a PMA violation).
- For the `sspush` and `sspopchk` SS-LP-CFI instructions, 16-bit compressed encodings (as well as 32-bit encodings) will be provided. Presently Zimop does not define compressed encodings - AR is working on allocating compressed Zimop encoding space.

In issue #48 we discussed whether we need to support `sspush` with all sources or they can be constrained to `x1` and `x5`. Especially with this update to combine the `sspop` and `sschkra`, we would want to take the opportunity to do that and free up some of the other encodings.

The updates are as summarized:
1. Update `sspush` and `sspop` to support only `x1` and `x5` as source and destination respectively
2. Drop the `sschkra` instruction
3. Define a `sspopchk` instruction
4. Add compressed encoding's SS-LP-CFI `sspush` and `sspopchk` instructions

The `sspopchk` has a register source rs1 and no destination (rd is x0). 
Only `x1` and `x5` are supported encodings for `rs1`.
Its operation is as follows:
```
If (xBCFIE = 1)
    temp = *[ssp] # Load temp from address in ssp
    if temp != [rs1] 
        Raise illegal-instruction exception
    endif
    [ssp] = [ssp] + (XLEN/8) # increment ssp by XLEN/8    
endif
```

issues.title: setjmp/longjmp example (at end of section 3.2)
issues.body:
### 1. Implicit assumption that setjmp is a leaf function and doesn't spill to the shadow stack

The spec mentions that the compiler/author can choose not to use the shadow stack for leaf functions, but does not mandate it [1]. However, this optimization is assumed by the setjmp/longjmp example; if setjmp did spill to the shadow stack, there would be an off-by-one error in longjmp: it would be partially restoring the state of setjmp, not setjmp's caller.

Could this assumption be made explicit in the text?

[1]

> A leaf function i.e. a function that does not itself make function calls does not need to push the link register to the shadow stack or pop it from the shadow stack in either shadow stack mode or in control stack mode. The return value *may* be held in the link register itself for the duration of the leaf function execution.

(emphasis added)

There is somewhat stronger wording in the Introduction:

> The shadow stack is used to spill the link register if required by non-leaf functions.

but I read that as a suggestion of where the shadow stack could be used, not as an exclusion of other uses.

----

### 2. Editorial: confusing code comment for setjmp

```
  // read and save top of stack pointer to jmp_buf
  asm("ssprr %0" : "=r"(cur_ssp):);
  jmp_buf->saved_ssp = cur_ssp;
```

Should this comment be "read and save shadow stack pointer to jmp_buf"? I interpreted the comment to be referring to the code that immediately follows.

(The existing comment could be argued to be technically correct, because setjmp does typically save the (non-shadow) stack pointer, or thereabouts.)

----

### 3. Editorial: guard pages are mentioned in the context of longjmp/setjmp, which is partly out of context

The text currently reads:

> The unwind function must verify that it does not accidentally unwind past the bounds of the shadow stack. Shadow stacks are expected to be bounded on each end using guard pages i.e. pages that do not have a shadow stack attribute.


Unwinding justifies why a guard page is needed at the bottom of the shadow stack, but it does not explain why a guard page is needed at the top end of the shadow stack. I can imagine there are good reasons (not overflowing the shadow stack into user memory etc.), but it's not explained here (and the longjmp/setjmp section would not the proper place to do so). Perhaps the guard page requirement could be stated in section 3.5.1 (where the requirement to not alias writeable non-shadow-stack pages is listed)?


issues.title: Landing pad multi-labeling
issues.body:
###  Multi-labelling without call site specific entry points

In Chapter 1, a suggested use case is:

> For example, consider two call sites A and B. A invokes functions X and Y. B invokes functions Y and Z. With a
> single label scheme the functions X, Y, and Z would need to be assigned the same
> label such that both call site A and B can invoke the common function Y. This
> allows call site A to additionally call function Z and call site B to additionally call
> function X. However, if function Y was labeled with two labels - one corresponding
> to call site A and other to call site B then Y can be invoked by both, but the X can
> only be invoked by call site A and Z only by call site B. To support multiple labels,
> the compiler may create a call site specific entry-point to such shared functions
> with each entry-point containing the call site specific landing pad instruction
> followed by a direct branch to the start of the function.

It's possible to avoid the need for multiple call site specific entry points, by using the middle label:
```
Call site A:
- set lower label to 10
- set middle label to 20

Call site B:
- set lower label to 10
- [middle label is implicitly set by lpsll to 0]


X prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check middle label is 20

Y prologue:
- check lower label is 10

Z prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check middle label is 0
```
Perhaps this straightline code could be more efficient than the entrypoint trampolines?

### Using lower + upper label instead of lower + middle label?

The spec states:

> For label widths up to 17-bit a companion instruction lpcml is provided.
> ...
> A lpsml instruction is provided to set the value of the middle label (ML) field of the lpl. This
> instruction is used when labels wider than 9-bit are used.
>
> ...
> A lpsul instruction is provided to set the value of upper label (UL) field lpl. This instruction is used
when labels wider than 17-bit are used.

AFAICS it would be equally valid to use the lower+upper labels to handle the 17-bit case; i.e., it is legal to check the lower+upper labels without checking the middle label:
```
foo:
  lpsll $10
  lpsul $30 # Instead of lpsml
  jalr %ra, %x10

bar:
  lpcll $10
  lpcul $30 # Instead of lpcml
  : 
```

Is this allowed?

If so, the text is not quite accurate in stating that lpsml is used for >9-bit labels and lpsul is used for >17-bit labels.

Besides being a technicality, being able to check the upper label without checking the middle label gives additional multi-labelling (without call site specific entrypoint) flexibility e.g.,
```
Call site A:
- set lower label to 10
- set middle label to 20
- [high label is implicitly set to 0]

Call site B:
- set lower label to 10
- [middle label is implicitly set to 0]
- [high label is implicitly set to 0]

Call site C:
- set lower label to 10
- [middle label is implicitly set to 0]
- set high label to 30

Call site D:
- set lower label to 10
- set middle label to 20
- set high label to 30


X prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check middle label is 20

Y prologue:
- check lower label is 10

Z prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check middle label is 0

U prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check high label is 30

V prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check high label is 0
```
enables the CFI policy:
```
A -> {X, Y,       V}
B -> {   Y, Z,    V}
C -> {   Y, Z, U  }
D -> {X, Y,    U  }
```

Many more policies are possible by varying the combinations of label values.

### Wacky idea: split the label into more pieces

Currently, the 25-bits of the landing pad label are split into 9/8/8 low/mid/high bits. However, if it was split into more pieces (e.g., 7/6/6/6 bits, with four set/check landing pad instructions; or 5/5/5/5/5 with five instruction pairs, etc.), it will give even more flexibility to do multi-labelling without trampolines.

issues.title: Introduce compressed shadow stack instructions
issues.body:
Issue #58 discussed a set of updates to shadow stack instructions suggested by AR.
The updates are as summarized:

1.  Update sspush and sspop to support only x1 and x5 as source and destination respectively
2. Drop the sschkra instruction
3. Define a sspopchk instruction
4. Add compressed encoding's SS-LP-CFI sspush and sspopchk instructions

PR #59 addressed updates for items 1 through 3.

Closure of item 4 was pending definition of compressed Zimop - Zcmop - and their encodings.
These are now available from AR:

Zcmop 
---

Eight code points in the 16-bit encoding space are provided for MOPs:

c.mop.0, encoded in the reserved encoding space where c.lui x1, 0 would be encoded
c.mop.1 (c.lui x3, 0)
c.mop.2 (c.lui x5, 0)
...
c.mop.7 (c.lui x15, 0)

These instructions are defined to not write rd.  As with other MOPs, which registers they read is left up to the future definition of the op, but this encoding makes it convenient for these instructions to read x1, x3, ..., x15.

Although we generally expect these MOPs to be equivalent to some 32-bit MOP, the expansion (if any) is left to the future definition of the op.

---

For shadow stacks, the following encodings are suggested:

- c.mop.0 => sspush x1
- c.mop.2 => sspopchk x5

The use of these instructions is as follows:

```
prologue:
    addi sp, sp, -16
    c.sspush x1
    sd x1, 8(sp)
body:
    ...
    jal x1, other_procedure
    ...
epilogue:
    ld x5, 8(sp)
    c.sspopchk x5
    jr x5
```

issues.title: sspop vs. ssload+sspinc
issues.body:
Opened to continue discussion from this mail list [thread](https://lists.riscv.org/g/tech-ss-lp-cfi/message/36).

Initially, `sspop` was introduced as the only way to pop a return address from a shadow stack and was paired with  `sschkra` instruction to check  the shadow return address with that obtained from the data stack.  The `sspop` was motivated to reduce the code size of the program. Subsequently, a combination instruction `sspopchk` that  combined the functionality of the `sspop` and `sschkra` was introduced that leads to further code size reduction. The use of `sspopchk` is thus the preferred method for programs operating in shadow stack mode. With this change the `sspop` was retained to support the control stack mode. In control stack mode the program does not push a return address on the regular stack - the return address variable is held only on the shadow stack. 

While originally motivated, the `sspop` introduces certain complexities for implementations due to its dual-dest nature as discussed at length in the email thread referenced above.

The use of `sspop` compared to a instruction pair `ssload`+`sspinc` does not lead to a significant code size increase as illustrated below. The function in control stack mode uses 6 additional code bytes. The function in shadow stack mode uses 4 additional code bytes. The extra load and store to the regular stack is elided in control stack mode.
```
control_stack_mode:    shadow_stack_mode:
 addi sp, sp, -24            addi sp, sp, -32
-c.sdsp x1, 24(sp)           c.sdsp x1, 24(sp)
+c.sspush x1                +c.sspush x1
:                                    : 
-c.ldsp x5, 24(sp)           c.ldsp x5, 24(sp)
+ssload x1                  +c.sspopchk x5 
+sspinc $1
 addi sp, sp, 24             addi sp, sp, 32
 ret                         ret

```
The `sspinc` can now also be used by unwinders to do fast unwinding. The `ssp` CSR however will need to stay URW to support pthreads and coroutine type user mode thread switching.

To support the micro-architecture simplification, the following is proposed:
1. Drop `sspop` and redefine the code points presently defined for it as `ssload`
2. Introduce a `sspinc` instruction that increments `ssp` by a non-zero unsigned 5-bit immediate scaled by XLEN/8

`sspush` / `sspop`: Encoding ambiguity
milestones.body:
Two instructions: `sspush` and `sspop` share the same encoding except:
*   `sspush`: `rs1`==source operand, `rd`==0
*   `sspop`: `rs1`==0, `rd`==destination operand

If both `rs1` and `rd` are zero, `sspush x0` and `sspop x0` are indistinguishable.

Quoting "4.1. Push to and Pop from the shadow stack":
> the CFI extension provides the `x1` and `x5` variants of the shadow stack load and store.

It (this sentence from a note) suggests that `sspush` and `sspop` only allows either `x1` or `x5` but this is not clear from the specification.

How do we resolve this?  Here are some ideas to resolve:

1.  ~~Only allow `x1` and `x5` as `sspush` and `sspop` instruction operand~~
2.  Disallow `x0` on `sspush` and `sspop` instructions (but allow other registers)
3.  ~~Use different encodings (e.g. use different `funct3`) between `sspush` and `sspop` instructions~~
4.  ~~Define the special behavior (explicitly) if an operand of `sspush` or `sspop` is `x0` (I don't like this option though)~~

milestones.title: `ssamoswap`, `lpsll` and `lpcll`: Encoding ambiguity
milestones.body:
Those three instructions share the same encoding space (same major opcode, funct7 and funct3):

```
ssamoswap : 1000001 src||addr 100 dst 1110011
lpsll     : 1000001   0||LLPL 100   0 1110011
lpcll     : 1000001   1||LLPL 100   0 1110011
```

and `lpsll` and `lpcll` instructions are indistinguishable from the `ssamoswap` instruction with `rd` of `x0`.

If sharing the encoding space is expected, `ssamoswap` must prohibit destination zero register.

milestones.title: `sschkra`: strange encoding or operand ordering
milestones.body:
Despite that `sschkra` is encoded as `rs1==5` and `rs2==1`, the only example of this instruction shows: `sschkra x1, x5`.
If two operands are encoded as `rs1` and `rs2`, it usually means `rs1==1` and `rs2==5`.  This is rather strange.

Changing encoding and/or operands of this instruction may be required.
Note that not all options are mutually exclusive (e.g. 1 and 3 are not mutually exclusive).

1.  ~~Change encoding of `sschkra` so that `rs1==1` and `rs2==5`.~~
2.  Accept only `sschkra x5, x1` and change the example in the specification.
3.  ~~Accept both `sschkra x1, x5` and `sschkra x5, x1`, assign them the same opcode.~~
4.  ~~Remove both operands from the assembler mnemonics of `sschkra` (to encode `sschkra` instruction with just `sschkra`, not `sschkra x1, x5` or something) and make `x1` and `x5` implicit.~~

~~Note that `sschkra` instruction shares the same major opcode, funct7 and funct3 with `lpsul` and `lpcul` instructions but it is safe to swap `(rs1,rs2)==(5,1) â†’ (1,5)` as in option 1 because doing so does not cause crash to `lpsul` and `lpcul` instructions (to NOT crash with `lpsul` and `lpcul`, register number of `rs2` must be less than 16).~~

milestones.title: Errors on atomic swap example
milestones.body:
The backward-edge CFI provides following example for atomic swap.
```
# The a0 register holds the pointer to top of new shadow
# to switch to. The current ssp is first pushed on the current
# shadow stack and the ssp is restored from new shadow stack
save_shadow_stack_pointer:
    ssprr  x5                   # read ssp and push value onto
    sspush x5                   # shadow stack. The [ssp] now
                                # holds ssp+8. Save away x5
                                # into a context structure to
                                # restore later.
restore_shadow_stack_pointer:
    ssamoswap t0, a0, x0        # t0=*[ssp] and *[ssp]=0
    addi      t0, t0, (XLEN/8)  # t0+XLEN/8 must match to a0
    bnez      t0, a0, crash     # if not crash program
    csrw      ssp, t0           # setup new ssp
```
There is an error on restore function. The `a0` register is expected to hold the memory address stored the checkpoint, the value should be `ssp`. Therefore, the value of `*[a0]` is expected to be `ssp+(XLEN/8)`, and the `t0` register is holding the value after `ssamoswap` instruction. In order to check the equivalent of the `t0` and `a0` register, you need to add `(XLEN+8)` to the `a0` register instead of the `t0` register. The correct equation would be: `t0 == a0+(XLEN/8)`. The `t0` register is still holding the top return address pointer, `ssp+(XLEN/8)`, after equivalent check.

The updated example is shown as following:
```
# The a0 register holds the pointer to top of new shadow
# to switch to. The current ssp is first pushed on the current
# shadow stack and the ssp is restored from new shadow stack
save_shadow_stack_pointer:
    ssprr  x5                   # read ssp and push value onto
    sspush x5                   # shadow stack. The [ssp] now
    addi   x5, x5, -(XLEN/8)    # holds ssp+(XLEN/8). The [x5]
                                # now holds ssp. Save away x5
                                # into a context structure to
                                # restore later.
restore_shadow_stack_pointer:
    ssamoswap t0, a0, x0        # t0=*[a0] and *[a0]=0
                                # The [a0] should hold ssp
    addi      a0, a0, (XLEN/8)  # a0+XLEN/8 must match to t0
    bne       t0, a0, crash     # if not crash program
    csrw      ssp, t0           # setup new ssp
```

I think this CFI extension might be the target for physical attacks.

There is a risk that a lpcll may be maliciously transformed into a lpsll.
Or a lpcml into a lpcll

With a bit of luck an attacker may change the label expected value with a glitched landing pad of the same value...

I know that there is example for such type attacks on other architectures.

I link a paper that has a nice introduction to the issue (just read the physical Attacks section)

https://past.date-conference.com/proceedings-archive/2019/pdf/1074.pdf

I'm not sure but I think that it the binary distance between these two critical instructions was higher the risk might be reduced.

Was this issues considered? Is there any mitigation planned?

milestones.title: ELP behaviour on bad target instruction
milestones.body:
I ran into an issue with my implementation of forward CFI which, unless I am missing something, was caused by the proposed standard being incorrect.

"When ELP is set to LP_EXPECTED and the next instruction in the instruction stream is not lpcll, then an illegal instruction exception is raised. If the next instruction in the instruction stream is lpcll then the ELP updates to NO_LP_EXPECTED."
...
"When the instructions cause an illegal-instruction exception, the ELP does not change."

The second statement means that the fault handler will be entered with ELP still set. If forward CFI is enabled in the handler's mode (I was running tests in machine mode, so there was no way to avoid that) this in turn means that the first statement requires the fault handler to begin with a matching lpcll, or you get a never-ending fault loop...

There is a later statement:
"When a trap is taken into privilege mode x, the xPELP bits are updated with current ELP and ELP is set to NO_LP_EXPECTED."
but that is in a chapter that explicitly talks about:
"A trap may need to be delivered to the same or higher privilege level on completion of JALR but before the instruction at the target of JALR was decoded..."


I suggest removing the second statement above and making it clear what the intended behaviour is when faulting due to lack of lpcll after call (or when the ID is wrong).
In my "fixed" implementation, I now _always_ clear ELP for every instruction that is not supposed to actually set it. If ELP was set before there are then three possible situations:
1 The new instruction is a correct lpcll - everything is fine
2 There was an exception so the instruction was not executed - old ELP state copied into xPELP and exception handler called
3 The new instruction was not an lpcll, or was an lpcll at an unaligned address or with wrong ID - old ELP state copied into xPELP and fault handler called.
AFAICT, that should always work fine.


It is still unclear whether xPELP is supposed to be set when faulting in case 3.
Is it useful to be able to see in the fault handler whether this was a "normal" illegal instruction or a CFI error? I suppose one can still find that out by looking at the instruction.

milestones.title: Priority of forward CFI fault?
milestones.body:
In my implementation of CFI, the checks need to be done late in the CPU pipeline. This means that a lot of other things have been checked before it is decided whether a call target has the expected lpcll.
For example, the target instruction could be illegal, a misaligned branch, a faulting memory access etc.

All such things will of course also cause a fault handler to be called, and some of them will eventually cause the instruction in question to be restarted - whereupon any CFI fault will be taken.
Still, for the cases where an instruction restart does _not_ happen (there is another fatal fault), do we want there to be some kind of fault prioritization, or does it not matter?

Whether prioritization is expected or not should (IMHO) be documented.

milestones.title: Clarifying C instructions that are indirect call/jmp
Updates to shadow stack instructions
milestones.body:
Architecture committee reviewed the SS-LP-CFI instructions and various points of discussion led to the conclusion that the new SS-LP-CFI instructions will be common and code size will be a material concern and ARC has suggested the following updates:
- Combine `sspop` and `sschkra` into a single instruction - `sspopchk`. The pros and cons of combining two of the instructions into one somewhat more CISC'y instruction - to reduce code size (as well as eliminate use of a result Xreg and needing to specify it in the instruction encoding) - was discussed. The recommendation is to take this latter approach, resulting in just two SS-LP-CFI instructions (the CISCy-ness is considered very limited, especially when performed using cacheable idempotent memory, and felt to be justified in this case).
- The TG suggested that the `sspop` as defined is retained to support mode of operation where shadow stack is the only return address stack. This would be usable by `-march=native` binaries and also JIT code. Binaries built in this fashion will not be portable. There are issues with providing compressed instructions for both this purpose and for the shadow stack checking addition, and so the ARC proposes that only the shadow checking instructions would be have compressed format Zimops definitions, and the new ABI would need to use new non-Zimops instructions.
- The `sspush`,  `sspop`, `ssamoswap`, and `sspopchk` instructions should be specified as requiring use of idempotent cacheable memory (and otherwise a fault can be taken as a PMA violation).
- For the `sspush` and `sspopchk` SS-LP-CFI instructions, 16-bit compressed encodings (as well as 32-bit encodings) will be provided. Presently Zimop does not define compressed encodings - AR is working on allocating compressed Zimop encoding space.

In issue #48 we discussed whether we need to support `sspush` with all sources or they can be constrained to `x1` and `x5`. Especially with this update to combine the `sspop` and `sschkra`, we would want to take the opportunity to do that and free up some of the other encodings.

The updates are as summarized:
1. Update `sspush` and `sspop` to support only `x1` and `x5` as source and destination respectively
2. Drop the `sschkra` instruction
3. Define a `sspopchk` instruction
4. Add compressed encoding's SS-LP-CFI `sspush` and `sspopchk` instructions

The `sspopchk` has a register source rs1 and no destination (rd is x0). 
Only `x1` and `x5` are supported encodings for `rs1`.
Its operation is as follows:
```
If (xBCFIE = 1)
    temp = *[ssp] # Load temp from address in ssp
    if temp != [rs1] 
        Raise illegal-instruction exception
    endif
    [ssp] = [ssp] + (XLEN/8) # increment ssp by XLEN/8    
endif
```

milestones.title: Adding a stack diagram illustrating push and pop
Editorial changes on intro: typos and consistency
setjmp/longjmp example (at end of section 3.2)
milestones.body:
### 1. Implicit assumption that setjmp is a leaf function and doesn't spill to the shadow stack

The spec mentions that the compiler/author can choose not to use the shadow stack for leaf functions, but does not mandate it [1]. However, this optimization is assumed by the setjmp/longjmp example; if setjmp did spill to the shadow stack, there would be an off-by-one error in longjmp: it would be partially restoring the state of setjmp, not setjmp's caller.

Could this assumption be made explicit in the text?

[1]

> A leaf function i.e. a function that does not itself make function calls does not need to push the link register to the shadow stack or pop it from the shadow stack in either shadow stack mode or in control stack mode. The return value *may* be held in the link register itself for the duration of the leaf function execution.

(emphasis added)

There is somewhat stronger wording in the Introduction:

> The shadow stack is used to spill the link register if required by non-leaf functions.

but I read that as a suggestion of where the shadow stack could be used, not as an exclusion of other uses.

----

### 2. Editorial: confusing code comment for setjmp

```
  // read and save top of stack pointer to jmp_buf
  asm("ssprr %0" : "=r"(cur_ssp):);
  jmp_buf->saved_ssp = cur_ssp;
```

Should this comment be "read and save shadow stack pointer to jmp_buf"? I interpreted the comment to be referring to the code that immediately follows.

(The existing comment could be argued to be technically correct, because setjmp does typically save the (non-shadow) stack pointer, or thereabouts.)

----

### 3. Editorial: guard pages are mentioned in the context of longjmp/setjmp, which is partly out of context

The text currently reads:

> The unwind function must verify that it does not accidentally unwind past the bounds of the shadow stack. Shadow stacks are expected to be bounded on each end using guard pages i.e. pages that do not have a shadow stack attribute.


Unwinding justifies why a guard page is needed at the bottom of the shadow stack, but it does not explain why a guard page is needed at the top end of the shadow stack. I can imagine there are good reasons (not overflowing the shadow stack into user memory etc.), but it's not explained here (and the longjmp/setjmp section would not the proper place to do so). Perhaps the guard page requirement could be stated in section 3.5.1 (where the requirement to not alias writeable non-shadow-stack pages is listed)?

milestones.title: Landing pad multi-labeling
milestones.body:
###  Multi-labelling without call site specific entry points

In Chapter 1, a suggested use case is:

> For example, consider two call sites A and B. A invokes functions X and Y. B invokes functions Y and Z. With a
> single label scheme the functions X, Y, and Z would need to be assigned the same
> label such that both call site A and B can invoke the common function Y. This
> allows call site A to additionally call function Z and call site B to additionally call
> function X. However, if function Y was labeled with two labels - one corresponding
> to call site A and other to call site B then Y can be invoked by both, but the X can
> only be invoked by call site A and Z only by call site B. To support multiple labels,
> the compiler may create a call site specific entry-point to such shared functions
> with each entry-point containing the call site specific landing pad instruction
> followed by a direct branch to the start of the function.

It's possible to avoid the need for multiple call site specific entry points, by using the middle label:
```
Call site A:
- set lower label to 10
- set middle label to 20

Call site B:
- set lower label to 10
- [middle label is implicitly set by lpsll to 0]


X prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check middle label is 20

Y prologue:
- check lower label is 10

Z prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check middle label is 0
```
Perhaps this straightline code could be more efficient than the entrypoint trampolines?

### Using lower + upper label instead of lower + middle label?

The spec states:

> For label widths up to 17-bit a companion instruction lpcml is provided.
> ...
> A lpsml instruction is provided to set the value of the middle label (ML) field of the lpl. This
> instruction is used when labels wider than 9-bit are used.
>
> ...
> A lpsul instruction is provided to set the value of upper label (UL) field lpl. This instruction is used
when labels wider than 17-bit are used.

AFAICS it would be equally valid to use the lower+upper labels to handle the 17-bit case; i.e., it is legal to check the lower+upper labels without checking the middle label:
```
foo:
  lpsll $10
  lpsul $30 # Instead of lpsml
  jalr %ra, %x10

bar:
  lpcll $10
  lpcul $30 # Instead of lpcml
  : 
```

Is this allowed?

If so, the text is not quite accurate in stating that lpsml is used for >9-bit labels and lpsul is used for >17-bit labels.

Besides being a technicality, being able to check the upper label without checking the middle label gives additional multi-labelling (without call site specific entrypoint) flexibility e.g.,
```
Call site A:
- set lower label to 10
- set middle label to 20
- [high label is implicitly set to 0]

Call site B:
- set lower label to 10
- [middle label is implicitly set to 0]
- [high label is implicitly set to 0]

Call site C:
- set lower label to 10
- [middle label is implicitly set to 0]
- set high label to 30

Call site D:
- set lower label to 10
- set middle label to 20
- set high label to 30


X prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check middle label is 20

Y prologue:
- check lower label is 10

Z prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check middle label is 0

U prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check high label is 30

V prologue:
- check lower label is 10
- check high label is 0
```
enables the CFI policy:
```
A -> {X, Y,       V}
B -> {   Y, Z,    V}
C -> {   Y, Z, U  }
D -> {X, Y,    U  }
```

Many more policies are possible by varying the combinations of label values.

### Wacky idea: split the label into more pieces

Currently, the 25-bits of the landing pad label are split into 9/8/8 low/mid/high bits. However, if it was split into more pieces (e.g., 7/6/6/6 bits, with four set/check landing pad instructions; or 5/5/5/5/5 with five instruction pairs, etc.), it will give even more flexibility to do multi-labelling without trampolines.

Introduce compressed shadow stack instructions
milestones.body:
Issue #58 discussed a set of updates to shadow stack instructions suggested by AR.
The updates are as summarized:

1.  Update sspush and sspop to support only x1 and x5 as source and destination respectively
2. Drop the sschkra instruction
3. Define a sspopchk instruction
4. Add compressed encoding's SS-LP-CFI sspush and sspopchk instructions

PR #59 addressed updates for items 1 through 3.

Closure of item 4 was pending definition of compressed Zimop - Zcmop - and their encodings.
These are now available from AR:

Zcmop 
---

Eight code points in the 16-bit encoding space are provided for MOPs:

c.mop.0, encoded in the reserved encoding space where c.lui x1, 0 would be encoded
c.mop.1 (c.lui x3, 0)
c.mop.2 (c.lui x5, 0)
...
c.mop.7 (c.lui x15, 0)

These instructions are defined to not write rd.  As with other MOPs, which registers they read is left up to the future definition of the op, but this encoding makes it convenient for these instructions to read x1, x3, ..., x15.

Although we generally expect these MOPs to be equivalent to some 32-bit MOP, the expansion (if any) is left to the future definition of the op.

---

For shadow stacks, the following encodings are suggested:

- c.mop.0 => sspush x1
- c.mop.2 => sspopchk x5

The use of these instructions is as follows:

```
prologue:
    addi sp, sp, -16
    c.sspush x1
    sd x1, 8(sp)
body:
    ...
    jal x1, other_procedure
    ...
epilogue:
    ld x5, 8(sp)
    c.sspopchk x5
    jr x5
```

milestones.title: sspop vs. ssload+sspinc
milestones.body:
Opened to continue discussion from this mail list [thread](https://lists.riscv.org/g/tech-ss-lp-cfi/message/36).

Initially, `sspop` was introduced as the only way to pop a return address from a shadow stack and was paired with  `sschkra` instruction to check  the shadow return address with that obtained from the data stack.  The `sspop` was motivated to reduce the code size of the program. Subsequently, a combination instruction `sspopchk` that  combined the functionality of the `sspop` and `sschkra` was introduced that leads to further code size reduction. The use of `sspopchk` is thus the preferred method for programs operating in shadow stack mode. With this change the `sspop` was retained to support the control stack mode. In control stack mode the program does not push a return address on the regular stack - the return address variable is held only on the shadow stack. 

While originally motivated, the `sspop` introduces certain complexities for implementations due to its dual-dest nature as discussed at length in the email thread referenced above.

The use of `sspop` compared to a instruction pair `ssload`+`sspinc` does not lead to a significant code size increase as illustrated below. The function in control stack mode uses 6 additional code bytes. The function in shadow stack mode uses 4 additional code bytes. The extra load and store to the regular stack is elided in control stack mode.
```
control_stack_mode:    shadow_stack_mode:
 addi sp, sp, -24            addi sp, sp, -32
-c.sdsp x1, 24(sp)           c.sdsp x1, 24(sp)
+c.sspush x1                +c.sspush x1
:                                    : 
-c.ldsp x5, 24(sp)           c.ldsp x5, 24(sp)
+ssload x1                  +c.sspopchk x5 
+sspinc $1
 addi sp, sp, 24             addi sp, sp, 32
 ret                         ret

```
The `sspinc` can now also be used by unwinders to do fast unwinding. The `ssp` CSR however will need to stay URW to support pthreads and coroutine type user mode thread switching.

To support the micro-architecture simplification, the following is proposed:
1. Drop `sspop` and redefine the code points presently defined for it as `ssload`
2. Introduce a `sspinc` instruction that increments `ssp` by a non-zero unsigned 5-bit immediate scaled by XLEN/8
